column2: Can you clarify project sponser versus stakeholders?
column5:
The project sponsor is typically a high-level executive or individual who has the authority and responsibility to initiate, fund, and support the project.

Stakeholders are individuals or groups who have an interest or influence in the project. They can be internal or external to the organization. Stakeholders can include project team members, end-users, customers, executives, managers, suppliers, regulatory bodies, or community members. The project sponsor is a stakeholder.

column2: Project Chart is same  as Project Plan or its diffrent ?

column2: Project Chart is same  as Project Plan or its diffrent ?
column5:
A project charter and a project plan are two distinct documents that serve different purposes in project management. The project charter is a high-level document that formally authorizes the existence of a project and provides the project manager with the authority to proceed with project activities.

The project plan is a comprehensive document that outlines the detailed approach, activities, resources, and schedule for executing a project.

While the project manager often takes a leading role in overseeing the documentation process, it is common for subject matter experts, team members, and other stakeholders to contribute to the creation and maintenance of project documentation. 

With that in mind, many organizations develop their own templates for project documentation, which are often tailored to their specific needs and processes. These templates can be standardized across projects to ensure consistency and facilitate efficient documentation creation. If your organization does not keep or provide templates, the documents would need to be created from scratch or you can find sample templates online that may be a good starting point.

https://www.projectmanager.com/pm-templates

A good source of templates for many project management docuements is projectmanagement.com.
